title: Deportation 1/2
header: You will be forced out of Greece by the Greek authorities (deportation)
content:
You are not eligible to seek asylum status or subsidiary protection status in Greece and it is likely that you will be forced out of Greece by the Greek authorities (deportation).

Please note that there is a high chance that the Greek authorities will only deport you to Turkey and they will not be able to send you back to your country of origin or country of previous residence.

title: Deportation 2/2
header: You will be forced out of Greece by the Greek authorities (deportation)
content: Alternatively, you may check with International Organization of Migration (IOM) to see if there is a program for voluntary return to your country of origin or country of previous residence.

title: Please select the option of either be returned by the Greek authorities (deportation) or seek help from IOM to return you to your country of origin or country of previous residence
header: Please select the option of either be returned by the Greek authorities (deportation) or seek help from IOM to return you to your country of origin or country of previous residence
content: N/A

buttons.text: Seek help from IOM to return to country of origin

title: Deport to Turkey 1/3
header: Deport to Turkey
content: Please approach a Police Officer or staff in the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) to express verbally or in writing that you do not fall under any of the asylum categories and want to leave Greece or simply withdraw your asylum application.

title: Deport to Turkey 2/3
header: Deport to Turkey
content:
After your expression of interest that you want to leave Greece or want to withdraw your asylum application, the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will determine the date when you will leave Greece (deportation).

The Greek authorities can most likely only return you to Turkey and there is hardly any possibility for them to send you back to your home country or country of previous residence or choice.

A few days following your request to return to Turkey, the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will embark you on a boat and send you back to Turkey.

title: Seek help from IOM 1/3
header: Seek help from IOM
content: Please note you have five calendar days to benefit from Assisted Voluntary Return and Reintegration (AVRR) provided by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) if you do not qualify for asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece.

title: Seek help from IOM 2/3
header: Seek help from IOM
content:
Please note if you have benefited before from IOM’s Assisted Voluntary Return and Reintegration program, as you will not be able to do so for the second time.

Since you have five calendar days, if you are interested in benefiting from IOM’s Assisted Voluntary Return and Reintegration program, you must indicate such interest as soon as possible by contacting IOM’s representative.

title: Seek help from IOM 3/3
header: Seek help from IOM
content: Please contact an employee of the International Organization for Migration (IOM) at llll or info@iom.int or +41.22.717 9111 or +41.22.798 6150 to see if there is a program to voluntarily return to your country of origin or country of previous residence.  If there is such program, IOM officials will assist you with your return to your country of origin or country of previous residence.  You may find further information on IOM through their website: https://www.iom.int/.

title: End of Asylum
header: End of Asylum
content: You have reached the end of the asylum process.  Thank you for your time to go through this application.  We hope you have found the information provided here useful.  We wish you all our very best!

title: Disclaimer
header: Disclaimer
content:
This app walks you through the asylum procedure in Greece and provides you with more information on the process.  Please note this app only applies for individuals who arrived in Lesvos, Greece and they did so after March 2016.  

The app is set up in a way that it is intended to be informative, while providing you full choices on how to continue at each stage of the asylum process.  

You will have the option to revert to your previous choice or start over your walk-through of the process at any point.  Despite the fact that the app tries to be as informative as possible, its content cannot cover every single aspect of the asylum process.  

Therefore, once you complete your walk-through of the asylum process in the app, you are encouraged to see a lawyer to consult on your individual case.  We hope you will find the information captured in this app useful for you and your family.

title: Introduction
content: We will be asking you 5 quick questions to be able to better help you with the asylum procedure in Lesvos, Greece.  No one else than you will ever see the answers that you provide here.  Your responses will have absolutely no impact on your asylum application.

title: Arrival in Greece
header: Arrival in Greece
content: Arrival and First Screening

title: Hellenic Police Arrest to Bus
header: Hellenic Police Arrest to Bus
content: The Hellenic Police, the Hellenic Coast Guard, or FRONTEX (European Border Police) will arrest you, put you on buses, and bring you to a First Reception and Identification Center (Moria), which is a camp, registration and identification center. Also, a part of the camp is a detention center.

title: First Screening at MORIA Tent
header: First Screening at MORIA Tent
content: In the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria), there is a space for new arrivals. You will wait in a big tent set up inside the Center for the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX to do a first screening.

title: First Screening - FRONTEX screening
header: First Screening - FRONTEX screening
content: The Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will conduct the first screening.  They will ask for your name, nationality, and other personal details.  If you are stateless, please make sure to tell this to the officer conducting your first screening.

title: Reminders for First Screening 1/3
header: Reminders for First Screening 1/3
content:
Please provide any evidence that you have to prove your name, nationality, and other personal details to the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX official during your first screening.  Evidences will help to prove your statements are true and will help you with the asylum process.

Please mention to the officer of the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX if you are a victim of human trafficking, so they can provide you appropriate protection.

title: Reminders for First Screening 2/3
header: Reminders for First Screening 2/3
content: Please make sure everything you say and all the documents you provide is true and complete.  False or incomplete information will delay your asylum application and have negative consequences.  Fake information or false evidence will be very difficult to change later and might even cause the rejection of the asylum claim.

title: Reminders for First Screening 3/3
header: Reminders for First Screening 3/3
content:
During the first screening, the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will also take your fingerprints.  Your fingerprints will be entered into the European Dactyloscopy (Eurodac), the European Union’s fingerprint database for identifying asylum seekers.  They will also look for any criminal record by searching for your name in Interpol and other police databases.

In order to avoid any mistakes in your police file, at the end of the first screening, please read through and verify all information that you provided to the official of the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX.  Mistakes in your asylum application may delay or create complications for your case.

title: First Screening and Interview - Under 14
header: First Screening and Interview - Under 14
content:
If you are 14 years old or younger, you will not be separated from your family during the first screening and be interviewed together with one of your parents.

Children under 14 will not be interviewed and their data will be given to the official of EASO or the Regional Asylum Office by the parents during their interview.

title: First Screening and Interview
header: First Screening and Interview
content:
The first screening will be conducted individually, which means the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will question you without the presence of your family.

An interpreter will be available during the initial screening to help you with your responses.

title: First Screening - Police Report
header: First Screening - Police Report
content: Once the first screening is completed by the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX, they will give you a police report that includes your photo, personal details, as well as your police file number.  The police file number will later appear on your asylum application and international protection applicant’s card (commonly known as “ausweis”)

title: Vulnerability - First Screening
header: Vulnerability - First Screening
content:
After the first screening by the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX, you will have a basic medical checkup.

You will get a form in your mother tongue (or a language you understand) to check on any medical conditions you may have. At the end of the form there will be a box that you can check if you are vulnerable.

title: Vulnerability Confirmation - First Screening
header: Vulnerability Confirmation - First Screening
content: Based on your registration on this app, you are considered a vulnerable/non-vulnerable person.

title: Initial Medical Screening - 1/3
header: Initial Medical Screening - 1/3
content: When you have completed the medical form, a nurse or doctor will look at your responses, ask you some basic medical questions, and look for any serious illness.  No medical tests will be done at this point.

title: Initial Medical Screening - 2/3
header: Initial Medical Screening - 2/3
content: In case no medical form will be given to you at this point, you may request to receive such form in writing.  A lawyer may assist you to obtain a medical form that evaluates your health conditions and includes any potential illnesses you suffer from.  Such form can be helpful to determine whether you are considered vulnerable or not.

title: Initial Medical Screening - 3/3
header: Initial Medical Screening - 3/3
content: If the nurse or doctor does not identify any manifestation that you have any of the conditions that would characterize you to be a vulnerable person, you can request any medical organization to undergo a vulnerability assessment once the first screening is completed.  Such assessment can be conducted every month.

title: FRONTEX Screening Results
header: FRONTEX Screening Results
content: After your medical examination, the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX will determine if you are detained in the Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) or detained in (confined to) the territory of the larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) depending on the results of the first screening by the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX.  You will be detained because you did not pass through passport and visa control when you entered Greece and this is considered illegal.

title: FRONTEX Screening Results - Unaccompanied Minor
header: FRONTEX Screening Results - Unaccompanied Minor
content: If you are an unaccompanied minor, the authorities will care for your protection and you will be housed in a center for minors within the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria).

title: Learn more about detention options 1/2
header: Learn more about detention options 1/2
content:
This app will offer you information to learn more about the options of being detained in the Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) or detained in(confined to) the territory of the larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) for illustrative purposes.  

In reality, this decision is made by the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX and you have no control over it.

title: Learn more about detention options 2/2
header: Learn more about detention options 2/2
content: Which option would you like to learn?

buttons.text: Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (Actual Prison)
Detention in (confinement to) the territory of the larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria)

title: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center 1/5
header: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center

title: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center 2/5
header: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center
content:
You will be escorted to the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) by the Hellenic Police or FRONTEX and placed in an Isobox there.

You can be detained for up to 90 days depending on the reason for your detention.  The Police Director will make that decision and s/he must justify and explain that decision in detail.

If your presence in Greece is considered a threat to national security or public order, the Police will immediately arrest you and transfer you to Athens where they will determine what will next happen to you.

title: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center 3/5
header: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center
content: Even while you are in the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison), you have the right to get a lawyer free of charge to help you get released from the Detention Center and/or apply for asylum status in Greece.

title: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center 4/5
header: Actual Prison @ MORIA - Detention Center of First Reception and Identification Center
content:
The lawyer will file an objection against the decision of your detention on your behalf. S/he will do so in front of the President or the competent Judge of the Administrative Court of First Instance.

If you want to get a lawyer, please inform any of the UNHCR representatives in the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison).

title: Are you a non-Greek citizen or stateless person who has a well-founded fear of persecution?
header: Are you a non-Greek citizen or stateless person who has a well-founded fear of persecution because of the following?

title: Do you have a well-founded fear of suffering from a serious harm in your country of origin or country of previous residence because of the following reasons?
header: Do you have a well-founded fear of suffering from a serious harm in your country of origin or country of previous residence because of the following reasons?
content:
*You are in danger of facing the death penalty or execution, 

*You are in danger of facing torture,

*You are in danger of facing inhuman or degrading treatment, or

*Your life or physical integrity is in danger because of an international or civil war

title: Are you a non-Greek citizen who is transferred to Greece by a European state, which implements “Dublin III” Regulation and has regarded you a person seeking asylum?
header: Are you a non-Greek citizen who is transferred to Greece by a European state, which implements “Dublin III” Regulation and has regarded you a person seeking asylum?

title: You are eligible to seek asylum status or subsidiary protection status in Greece if you wish to do so.
header: Since you answered yes to at least one of the questions above, you are eligible to seek asylum status or subsidiary protection status in Greece if you wish to do so.

title: If you answered no to all of the above questions: Are you a non-Greek citizen or stateless person who faces dangers in your home country or country of residence, such as the death penalty, torture, or serious threat to your life due to general circumstances in the country or region you are from?
header: If you answered no to all of the above questions: Are you a non-Greek citizen or stateless person who faces dangers in your home country or country of residence, such as the death penalty, torture, or serious threat to your life due to general circumstances in the country or region you are from?

title: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece 1/5
header: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece
content:
We know, you might not want to live in Greece, but in another country of the European Union and Dublin III country, like Germany or a Northern European country.

There is no longer any realistic possibility of getting to another Dublin III country like Germany or any other Northern European country with the help of smugglers and applying for asylum there without claiming asylum in Greece.  The Greek borders are closed.

title: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece 2/5
header: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece
content:
Even in the unlikely event of succeeding in getting to another Dublin III country with the help of smugglers, you will most likely be caught and sent back to Greece to go through the asylum process there.

Once you apply for asylum in Greece, you must stay in Greece for the entire duration of the asylum process, until you get asylum or subsidiary protection status.  The entire duration of the asylum process may vary between a few months to even 4 years, depending on your case as well as the number of other asylum applications received by the Greek authorities.

title: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece 3/5
header: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece
content: The length of the asylum process can be very long, or too short in certain cases, which is very frustrating.  Please try to be patient and follow guidance provided by the Greek authorities and EASO, as well as guidance provided in this app, and advice of Greek lawyers to go through the process in the safest and fastest way.

title: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece 4/5
header: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece
content: Please do not trust smugglers.  They might approach you to offer their services.  They often lie to you and give you false hopes to make money for themselves and maintain their illegal businesses.  Hiring smugglers to try to leave Greece will harm your legal case, waste your money, and may even endanger your and your family’s life.

title: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece 5/5
header: You may seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece
content:
Once you get asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece, you can freely and legally move to another Dublin III country if you have your passport, but you must spend at least 3 months out of every 6 months period in Greece.  This means you must, for instance, stay in Greece between January and March out of January to June period.  However, you will not be allowed to work in any other Dublin III country except for Greece even after you get your asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece.

If you do not seek asylum in Greece, you will be arrested and forced to leave the country in days.

title: Would you wish to seek asylum status in Greece?
header: Would you wish to seek asylum status in Greece?

title: Submission of application for Asylum (MORIA Prison) 1/5
header: Submission of application for Asylum (MORIA Prison)
content:
Please approach a Police Officer or staff in the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) to express verbally or in writing that you want to seek asylum status in Greece.  The detention or first reception services official will then inform the Greek Asylum Service regarding your wish to submit an application for asylum.

You need to know that an international protection applicant cannot be detained just for the reason that s/he entered and remains in the country illegally; hence, as soon as you apply for international protection you will be released except in certain exceptional circumstances mentioned earlier.

title: Submission of application for Asylum (MORIA Prison) 2/5
header: Submission of application for Asylum (MORIA Prison)
content:
Please approach a Police Officer or staff in the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) to express verbally or in writing that you want to seek asylum status in Greece.  The detention or first reception services official will then inform the Greek Asylum Service regarding your wish to submit an application for asylum.

You need to know that an international protection applicant cannot be detained just for the reason that s/he entered and remains in the country illegally; hence, as soon as you apply for international protection you will be released except in certain exceptional circumstances mentioned earlier.

title: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison) 3/5
header: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison)
content:
If you submit an application for international protection while you are in detention due to illegal entry into the country or because your return to your country of origin is still pending, the Hellenic Police may decide that you must remain in detention in exceptional cases (if they do not see any other way), for the following reasons:

for the verification of your true identity or country of origin; or

for the determination of those elements on which the application for international protection is based which may not be obtained in the absence of detention, in particular when there is a risk of escape; or

when there are reasons to believe that you make the application for international protection just to delay or frustrate the enforcement of the return decision; or

if your presence in the country is considered a threat to national security or public order.

title: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison) 4/5
header: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison)
content:
Once you are released from the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison), please approach an European Asylum Support Office (EASO) staff in the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) within 10 days following your arrival to express verbally or in writing that you want to seek asylum status in Greece.

European Asylum Support Office (EASO) will subsequently schedule the full registration of your application, within which European Asylum Support Office (EASO) will fill out a registration form for international protection on your behalf.

title: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison) 5/5
header: Submission of application for asylum (MORIA Prison)
content:
The registration form will include a number, which is considered your case number to submit an application for asylum.  From the time you receive your application number until your application is examined at the first instance and, in case, at the appellate stage, you cannot be forced to leave Greece (deportation).

If you submit an application for international protection while you are detained for having committed a crime as defined under the penal code, you will remain in detention until you have served your sentence.

Access to international protection (asylum) procedure system is free of charge.

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 1/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 1/5
content:
You have the right to get a lawyer for money or for free to assist you during the asylum process.

If you have identified yourself to fall under at least one of the vulnerable categories but the nurse or doctor who conducted your initial medical screening did not categorize you under a vulnerable category, you may request to undergo a vulnerability assessment.

If you want to undergo a vulnerability assessment, please approach an officer at the Detention Center of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) (actual prison) to let them know that you want to get the assessment.

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 1/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 1/5
content:
You may be scheduled either a physical or psychological assessment free of charge and will be transported to the medical facility where the assessment will take place.

During the physical or psychological assessment, the doctor conducting the assessment will determine whether you fall under at least one of the vulnerable categories.

An employee of UNHCR, or an NGO (EuroRelief in Moria) will place you in a tent or Isobox at the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) depending on availability.

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 2/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 2/5
content:
You are not allowed to leave Lesvos island by law, but you may move freely within the island.

Your detention (confinement to) the territory of the larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) may last from 45 days to 18 months.  After your confinement period, you can travel outside the larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) or be forced to return to Turkey (deportation).

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 3/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 3/5
content:
Please note there is no longer any realistic possibility of getting to another Dublin III country before claiming asylum in Greece.  The Greek borders are closed.  There is no realistic chance to succeed in getting to Germany or Northern Europe with the help of smugglers.
There is a possibility to succeed in getting to Athens by smugglers, but that will not help you, but harm your legal case.  Even if you get to Athens or the Greek mainland with the help of smugglers, you might have to be sent back to Lesvos to start your asylum application if you wish to apply for asylum.

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 4/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 4/5
content: Please do not trust smugglers.  They may approach you to offer their services.  They routinely lie to you and provide you false hopes to make money for themselves and maintain their illegal businesses.  Hiring smugglers to leave Lesvos will harm your legal case, waste your money, and may even endanger your and your family’s life.

title: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 5/5
header: Detention @ MORIA Territory - Territory of the Larger First Reception and Identification Center (Moria) 5/5
content: While you are confined to the territory of the First Reception and Identification Center (Moria), you have the right to seek asylum or subsidiary protection status in Greece if you are eligible.

*race,

		*You are in danger of facing torture,
